column4: how can i modify my /etc/hosts regarding of an ip from an eth device?
background: i want my own hostname to be connected with the ip which was assigned by dhcp
yes but i get my ip from a dhcp. so it isnt static
Why don't you just use 127.0.0.1 for it? /etc/hosts won't affect any other computers, only your own
i need it for ipsec.conf. there i entered my hostname so that i can use my ipsec tunnel on every generic lan which has dhcp
I guess you'll have to edit the config of dhclient, to auto-modify /etc/hosts
No, 'supersede' only makes it use the one in /etc/hostname instead of the one from DHCP.
But doesn't affect /etc/hosts in any way.
But dunno, maybe you'll find a way to make it work... In any case, sed -i "s/^\\([0-9.]\\+\\) \\(foohost #dhcp\\)$/$NEW_IP \2/" /etc/hosts, if you're gonna script it.
It's just a comment, to avoid changing the wrong line in /etc/hosts (in case there are two lines with the same hostname)
$NEW_IP is this a variable from dhclient?
It's a variable from your script. (I don't have dhclient, so I don't know how do you actually script dhclient...)
ah ok but thanks for the sed line :)
